An exploration table of 4 magic operators that make composite polytopes: join, A ∨ B (make pyramid or wedge things), rhombic sum, A + B (make rhombic things), rectangular product A × B (hypercubes), and meet A ∧ B (skew polytopes).
The magic part is if you have f-vectors of A, and B, you can compute new f-vector as a products!
The only difference is whether you add a lead nullitope 1 element (join and rhombic), or trailing 1 body element (join and rectangle).

title: Brust’s JHEGAALA, smart, hard-boiled swords and sorcery with great poleconomy subtext – Cory Doctorow's MEMEX

last_post.content:
In *Jhegaala* (2009), the eleventh novel, it's a deep dive into the reactionary political economy of high fantasy, structured as a retelling of Hammett's *Red Harvest*:

https://memex.craphound.com/2009/08/20/brusts-jhegaala-smart-hard-boiled-swords-and-sorcery-with-great-poleconomy-subtext/

In *Iorich* (2010), book twelve, we get a treatise on the true nature of policing, law, and the rule of law itself, and how an institution designed to defend the status quo can be seized and mobilized in service to radical political projects:

https://memex.craphound.com/2010/01/12/steven-brusts-iorich-sword-and-sorcery-and-law-and-order/

https://memex.craphound.com/2010/01/12/steven-brusts-iorich-sword-and-sorcery-and-law-and-order/

21/

Partly, that's because of the brilliant stuff Brust is doing with the series as a whole. But moreso, it's because Brust is *ridiculously* clever in finding new framing devices for these titles. In *Dzur* (2006), the tenth Vlad novel, the entire story is told through the preparation and consumption of a meal that will make you slaver for a taste:

https://memex.craphound.com/2006/09/05/steven-brusts-dzur-witty-and-exciting-heroic-fantasy/

title: Listen up: you really owe it to yourself to read 15 Vlad Taltos novels, seriously – Cory Doctorow's MEMEX

last_post.content:
The elucidation of Cawti and Vlad's romance works superbly as a puzzle-piece to cast previous volumes in entirely new light, producing a series of *a-ha!* moments as aspects of the characters' motivations in early books materialize.

The most aggravating thing about discussing social media with some people is the persistent belief that the likes of #Twitter and #Meta are all-powerful, and there's nothing you can do about it.

That's straight up poppycock.

Not even Twitter and Meta believe that. If that were true, Twitter wouldn't have provided seed funding for #Bluesky, and Meta wouldn't be building #Barcelona. They're building these things because they perceive that the Fediverse -- correctly -- is a threat.

And why do they know the Fediverse is a threat? Because it's the most revolutionary communications technology in decades.

ansate finished reading "What Fresh Hell Is This?"

Did you know? a uniform aluminum sphere with 10 cm radius moving at 10 km/s has 550 megajoules of kinetic energy. That's 131 kg of TNT

KE scales with the cube of sphere radius so a 1 cm sphere at 10 km/s has 0.55 MJ -- about one Mk3 hand grenade (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MK3_grenade)

If a debris object has annual cumulative collision probability ~1% and takes 2 collisions to fall to 1 cm fragment sizes, it'll take ~200 years till collisions bring its frags below a hand grenade's energy

When I was in Wellington, New Zealand, I was entranced by their unusual crosswalk icons. I asked my new friends there about them. I was told a story about a drag performer and activist by the name of Carmen Rupe. She was a trans woman who was also Māori (native people of NZ).

Her story is pretty cool. And it’s awesome that NZ honored her this way.

title: Clean Energy 24/7: Engineers Use Nanotechnology To Harvest Electricity “From Thin Air”

last_post.content:
[holy crap]

Clean Energy 24/7: Engineers Use Nanotechnology To Harvest Electricity “From Thin Air”

Engineers at the University of Massachusetts Amherst have developed a technique for harvesting electricity from air humidity, dubbed the “generic Air-gen effect.” According to research published in Advanced Materials, any material with nanopores less than 100 nanometers in diameter can be utilized to continuously generate electricity.

According to @mastodonusercount@mastodon.social, there are now 12 million #Mastodon accounts.

This is good news for the growth of the #Fediverse, but there's a caveat.

Other than on mastodon.social, Mastodon sign-ups are slowing down. In my own estimation, the majority of Mastodon servers aren't experiencing any growth -- and many are losing users too.

At one point, https://joinmastodon.org was critical for driving sign-ups amongst many Mastodon servers. But from what numerous admins tell me, sign-ups from there have slowed to a trickle.

With https://home.social closing down soon, I fear this is a harbinger for more big server shutdowns. That is, unless something is done.

However, Mastodon isn't the entirety of the story.

It looks like *key apps are spurring more user adoption.

#Misskey is now the 2nd most used Fediverse software after Mastodon.

And within a month, #Calckey has nearly doubled in size -- despite the flagship server (which I admin) overcoming a few key challenges.

Of course, the arrival of #Barcelona will change everything. How? I don't entirely know.

But now with 12 million Mastodon accounts, it's time for the next chapter of the Fediverse.
